Business https://www.economist.com/business/ Business - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 7 月 13 日星期四 10:08:47 GMT 120 Is big business really getting too big?

政府正在与大企业交战。六月，美国总统乔·拜登代表世界各地许多政治家发言，将贪婪助长的物价上涨、工资增长缓慢、创新被放弃和供应链脆弱归咎于经济。 他在联邦贸易委员会（ FTC ）的反垄断机构一直在追查大笔交易，仅仅因为它们规模很大——或者至少感觉上是这样。法庭上的失败并没有削弱该机构的热情。最新的消息发生在 7 月 11 日，法官驳回了阻止微软以 690 亿美元收购视频游戏开发商动视暴雪 (Activision Blizzard) 的请求。预计联邦贸易委员会将对这一裁决提出上诉。欧盟竞争主管机构正在发出要分拆谷歌的声音。去年，英国竞争与市场管理局 ( CMA ) 阻止了半导体巨头英伟达 (Nvidia) 以 400 亿美元收购芯片设计公司 Arm 的交易。

反垄断者为其重新焕发活力提出了三个理由：市场集中度提高、全球最大公司的流失率减少以及企业利润上升。从表面上看，这三者都表明企业实力不断增强。但仔细观察，这些趋势可能是技术进步和全球化等良性因素的结果。矛盾的是，在一些当地市场，更大的集中度可能导致竞争加剧，而不是减少。而新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 疫情可能为竞争进一步复苏埋下了种子。确实，一些大公司一直在收取租金，包括医疗保健等大型行业。但反垄断者的策略——本能地质疑任何涉及大公司的交易——是错误的。

集中度一直在上升是毫无疑问的。就美国经济而言，今天的水平至少比上个世纪的任何时候都要高（见图 1）。在《经济学人》追踪的美国约 900 个行业中，四大公司市场份额超过三分之二的行业数量已从 1997 年的 65 个增加到 2017 年的 97 个。至少20年来一直在增加。三位经济学家 Gabor Koltay、Szabolcs Lorincz 和 Tommaso Valletti 使用西欧最大经济体（英国、德国、法国、意大利和西班牙）的数据发现，在大约 700 多个行业中，四大公司的市场份额增长了 73%从1998年到2019年，平均增幅约为7个百分点。 1998年至2019年，份额在50%以上的企业比例从行业的16%增加到27%。英国和法国的增幅最大。

与此同时，现有公司看起来更加根深蒂固。在英国，三年后市场份额保持在行业前十位的公司平均数量为金融危机前的五家。现在已经接近八点了。纽约大学斯特恩商学院的托马斯·菲利蓬发现，美国顶尖企业的客户流失率也有类似的下降。

最能说明问题的是，企业正在赚取更高的利润。 《经济学人》对全球市值最大的 3,000 家上市公司（不包括金融公司）的“超额”利润进行了粗略估计。根据彭博社报道的数据，我们计算出一家公司投资资本的最低回报率超过 10%（不包括商誉以及将研发视为寿命为 10 年的资产）。这是人们在竞争市场中可能期望的回报率。去年，超额利润达到 4 万亿美元，相当于全球GDP的近 4%（见图 2）。他们高度集中在西方，尤其是美国。美国公司占总数的 41%，欧洲公司占 21%。相对于其规模，能源、技术以及美国的医疗保健行业作为超额利润池脱颖而出。

这一切看起来都令人不安。在某些领域确实如此。四十年前，超过十分之八的医院都是非营利性的，只有一个地点。现在，超过十分之六的医院属于庞大的营利性连锁医院或学术网络，例如 Steward Health Care 或印第安纳大学健康中心 (Indiana University Health)。起初，这是大型高效连锁店在美国扩张的一个完全健康的过程。二十年过去了，近 2,000 家医院被合并，事情看起来进展缓慢。卡内基梅隆大学的马丁·盖纳 (Martin Gaynor) 及其同事在 2019 年进行的一项分析表明，此类合并往往会提高价格，而不会提高质量。

尽管如此，高集中度、低流失率和丰厚的利润并不一定会让消费者的境况变得更糟。一百年来，这种浓度一直在上升，在此期间，几乎每个人的生活都得到了改善，这是第一个线索，表明这可能是良性力量的结果。芝加哥大学布斯商学院的马跃然及其同事表示，过去一个世纪美国产业集中度的提高与技术强度的提高、固定成本的提高和产出增长的加快有关。这些似乎都不是特别邪恶。

这种集中度在欧洲也有所上升，那里的竞争主管机构并不像美国那样昏昏欲睡，这同样表明强大的结构性力量正在发挥作用。伦敦经济学院的约翰·范·雷宁 (John Van Reenen) 谈到了技术和全球化。互联网降低了货比三家的成本，尽管软件和其他技术使最好的公司能够扩大其在全球的业务规模。咨询公司麦肯锡收集的数据显示，按此衡量标准，位于 75% 的公司的投资资本回报率比中位数公司高 20 个百分点。 “软件可以产生巨大的规模经济，”研究公司 MoffettNathanson 的斯特林·奥蒂 (Sterling Auty) 说道。

当地的反英雄

此外，国家层面的高度集中可能会增加当地的竞争。尤其是服务业，在美国人口普查的 900 多个行业中约占一半，在地方一级得到了更好的审查。现任耶鲁大学管理学院前副助理总检察长菲奥娜·斯科特·莫顿（Fiona Scott Morton）以咖啡店为例。如果每个街区只有一家咖啡馆，全国市场就会极度分散。但每个消费者都将面临当地的垄断。 “如果我想喝杯咖啡，我不会开车三个小时，”她说。

学术界对于本地市场集中度到底发生了什么争论不休。越来越明显的是，最好的公司已经扩展到越来越多的公司。沃尔玛以其“每日低价”迎合美国各地的购物者，这要归功于这家零售巨头无与伦比的物流运作。 Cheesecake Factory 使用加利福尼亚州的一个实验室来品尝菜肴，并迅速将其推广到全美 200 多个地点。芝加哥大学的埃斯特班·罗西-汉斯伯格及其合著者最近发表的一篇题​​为“服务业的工业革命”的论文表明，大公司的地理扩张加剧了对当地现有企业的竞争，导致当地市场份额下降。

至于低流失率，如果现有企业不断创新——这也是许多企业正在做的事情——那么情况还不错。尽管各国央行以数十年来最快的速度加息，试图抑制通胀，但 2023 年第一季度美国私人投资占GDP的 17.2%，与大流行前的高点相似。许多企业巨头正在投入数十亿美元进行创新，包括最令反垄断机构担忧的领域，例如技术。美国科技巨头 Alphabet、亚马逊、苹果、Meta 和微软去年总共投入了约 2000 亿美元的研发资金，约占 2021 年美国研发总额的四分之一。微软和 Alphabet 处于人工智能竞赛的前沿。

确实，自 2007-09 年金融危机以来，美国的利润比过去几十年要高，尤其是考虑到自由现金流，它解释了公司资产折旧方式的变化（见图 3）。但如果你根据较低的税率和公司更大的全球足迹进行调整，它们看起来就不那么不寻常了。它们可能已经见顶：分析师估计，美国蓝筹股标准普尔500指数的盈利在截至 6 月份的三个月内同比下降，这是连续第三个季度下降。

最令人振奋的是，活力不但没有减弱，反而正在上升。马里兰大学的 John Haltiwanger 指出，自 2010 年代中期以来，企业组建一直“相当贫乏”，但自疫情爆发以来，企业组建数量激增（见图 4）。在过去的几年里，新公司的成立比被关闭的老公司还要多。这些初创公司是否会取代现有企业仍不清楚。但风险投资表明投资者看到了健康回报的空间。尽管这一数字仅为 2021 年第四季度超过 1300 亿美元泡沫峰值时的一半，但这仅使其回到了 2019 年和 2020 年的水平。

一种假设是，后疫情时代经济的远程友好性降低了启动成本。年轻的公司不再需要租用大办公室。他们可以从本地人才库中招聘人才。根据我们的粗略统计，人口普查局的 900 多个行业中，约有 125 个行业受益于不断发展的电子商务或可以远程提供服务。消费者对这些选择越来越满意，可能会激励更多新企业开店。哈尔蒂万格先生已经观察到企业规模分布发生了向小型企业的小幅转变。

由于交易减少，尤其是科技领域的交易，集中度也可能趋于平稳。自拜登上任以来，五大科技公司在美国上市公司所有收购中所占的份额已从 2010 年代的近 1% 下降到不足 0.5%。并购（ M ＆ A ）放缓的部分原因是资本成本上升和经济衰退风险造成的。但新一轮的反垄断热情一定发挥了作用。 6 月 27 日，美国当局 45 年来首次更新了合并指南，要求企业报告价值超过 1.1 亿美元的交易的更多细节，该交易规模是 2022 年平均交易规模的一半。

最大的交易几乎肯定会受到深入调查，这可能会使现在需要数周时间的归档过程增加数月时间。一位律师叹息道，各地监管机构都在“向并购机器的齿轮中扔沙子”。另一位人士表示：“联邦贸易委员会已经不再具有洞察力了。”一位英国人回应道，英国的CMA“可能做得有些过头了”。

这种过度热心的破坏信任行为本身也存在风险。它可能会分散人们对土地使用或职业许可官僚限制对经济活力更直接威胁的注意力。当市场低迷导致创始人难以筹集资金时，收购对于保护初创公司的价值很有用。一些大交易可能会让消费者受益，例如生物技术初创公司与老牌制药商联手测试和分销新疗法。竞争主管部门可能睡得太久了。现在他们可能起得太快了。 ■

; Wed, 12 Jul 2023 18:47:07 GMT /内容/dau82eooss0gq4qo6ctnrdudri4d2kb0 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/12/is-big-business-really-getting-too-big The last, unfulfilled dream of Jamie Dimon, king of Wall Street

杰·艾米·戴蒙焦躁不安。摩根大通的老板刚从 7 月 4 日的长假周末回来，带着他的大家庭和不断壮大的家庭：他的妻子、三个女儿和一群孙子。他对视频采访中的那些胡言乱语几乎没有耐心——这就是他、他的经理人、摄制组、专栏作家和《经济学人》主编聚集在美国最大银行的纽约总部的原因。戴蒙先生不想在走廊里闲逛以进行“走进”拍摄；他不想在走廊里闲逛。他也不会等到戴好麦克风并坐在椅子上才开始谈论公共政策。 “那么我们应该这样做吗？”他敦促道。

做事是戴蒙的方式。他缺乏耐心、机会主义、务实：是那种随遇而安的人。当戴蒙先生的 12 年级微积分老师离开后，他开始自学。刚从商学院毕业的他在美国运通找到了一份工作，因为他想要创造一些东西，而不仅仅是转移资金。他在执掌摩根大通近 18 年的时间里，打造出了相当于凡尔赛宫或泰姬陵的银行业。它是美国最成功的银行，并且市值达 4,350 亿美元，是迄今为止世界上最有价值的银行。在戴蒙先生的领导下，其股东获得了 10.6% 的可观年回报率，是大多数其他大型贷款机构的两倍。它的投资银行在几乎所有它想参与竞争的业务中都名列前三。它的商业银行是美国最大的。因为它规模太大——而且因为美国银行存款占总存款的10%以上，被禁止收购更多银行（除非它们拯救一家濒临破产的银行，就像摩根大通四月份对第一共和国所做的那样）——它只能缓慢增长。

那么，对于一个愿意做事的人来说，没有什么可做的了。 （一个名副其实的建设项目，他的银行位于公园大道的新总部，可能根本无法满足戴蒙先生的渴望。）相反，他将看似取之不尽用之不竭的精力转向了其他问题。他跳过了银行业的小型危机（大部分已解决）或经济衰退的风险（可能是温和的，也可能不是；无论哪种方式，他更担心乌克兰和非洲的粮食安全）。他对其他话题最感兴趣：社会流动性、缓和全球冲突和捍卫资本主义，他认为这些话题受到了不公平的诽谤。他每年写给股东的信，曾经仅限于对管理和银行业的思考，现在比典型的美国政治竞选活动包含更多的政策思考。

他为他最希望美国能够解决的问题提供了解决方案。为了实现社会流动性，他扩大了工资收入税收抵免，并一再抱怨教育成本。 “我们需要在社区大学方面做得更好，”他认为，“我们应该让它变得更便宜，而不是更贵。”

戴蒙先生渴望与中国进行公开对话，他认为美国作为迄今为止更繁荣的国家不应该害怕中国。中国人没有“十英尺高”。他们进口石油，缺乏粮食安全，更加贫穷，武装力量也较弱。 “也许他们在几个领域已经迎头赶上，但美国必须如此害怕中国的观念：我们不。”他认为转向产业政策以保护国家安全是明智的。但美国必须谨慎使用出口管制等工具。 “如果涉及超音速导弹，我认为我们应该这样做。如果这涉及到压制中国人民，我认为我们不应该这样做。”

尽管他早期支持“利益相关者价值”的理念，即考虑公司如何对待工人、供应商、整个社会或环境，但他并不是觉醒的资本家。相反，他是一个实用主义者。他认为，所有首席执行官都试图拥有最好的产品或服务，他们需要优秀的员工并让客户满意。 “这只是人性化的业务，我们照顾我们的客户、员工或工作人员等。”这并没有使他成为一个“热血、热情、自由进取、爱国的美国人”。

戴蒙先生对公共政策、决心、资源和雄心的兴趣都指向一个方向：政治职位。多年来，有关总统竞选的猜测不断涌现。但他很快就否决了这个想法。 “我从来没有真正相信自己特别适合它，”他说。 “在行政、管理、领导力方面……可能存在共同技能，但这些并不罕见。”知道如何驾驭政治舞台或竞选活动更加困难。戴蒙先生认为从商界转向政界是很棘手的。 “我认为这很难做到。事实上，如果我们只看历史，这几乎是不可能的。”唐纳德·特朗普总统是例外，而不是规则。这并不是一种恭维。 “我会担心特朗普再次当选总统，”他说。对于美国来说，转向国内并放弃其在世界上的地位将是一个巨大的错误。

戴蒙是永远的吗？

如果不是自由世界的领导人，也许是内阁秘书？ “也许有一天这会成为现实，”戴蒙先生若有所思地说。 “我爱我的国家。对我来说，我的家庭是第一位的。但我的国家紧随其后，”他解释道。 “摩根大通就在这里，”他指着下面补充道。他内心的现实主义者可能知道，任命财政部这个最明显的职位是不可能的。从华尔街到政府的道路不再像以前那样人迹罕至。长期以来，民主党人一直对高额金融持怀疑态度，而在民粹主义特朗普的领导下，共和党人的疑虑更加严重。 “摩根大通是我能做出的最大贡献，”戴蒙先生坚称。 “我们有 30 万名员工。我们很好地照顾他们，也给他们机会。”一个政客说得再好不过了。 ■

; Tue, 11 Jul 2023 13:04:54 GMT /内容/bso0mkfi7litiv9uidvughm4tor8en96 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/11/the-last-unfulfilled-dream-of-jamie-dimon-king-of-wall-street The fight over working from home goes global

远程工作有一个目标。银行业首席执行官，例如摩根大通的杰米戴蒙，决心让在家工作成为流行病的遗迹。美国最大的银行和高盛等其他华尔街巨头的员工发现，五天工作周又回来了。大型科技公司也在加大力度。谷歌的重返工作岗位任务可能会跟踪出勤情况，并将其纳入对叛逆员工的绩效评估中。 Meta 和 Lyft 希望员工回到办公桌前，要求在夏末之前每周至少有三天在办公室工作。随着老板们对这种做法进行限制，大流行时代就远程工作的可取性达成共识的日子似乎已经结束了。

一项全球调查的最新数据显示了这种共识已经被打破的程度。 WFH Research 表示，在世界各地，雇主的远程工作计划都达不到工人的期望。WFH Research 是一个由斯坦福大学和德国智库 Ifo 研究所组成的组织，该组织一直在追踪全职工人的情绪在 34 个国家至少接受过中等教育。企业老板担心完全远程工作会降低生产力，最近的大量研究强化了这种担忧。一项针对印度数据录入人员的研究发现，那些在家工作的人的工作效率比经常在办公室工作的同事低 18%；另一项研究发现，一家亚洲大型IT公司的员工在家中的工作效率比在办公室低 19%。微软近 62,000 名员工的通讯记录显示，随着远程工作的兴起，公司内部的专业网络变得僵化并变得更加孤立。

然而，来自上面的所有压力并没有削弱员工对远程工作的兴趣。 WFH Research 表示，员工希望能够比现在在舒适的客厅里工作更多天。平均而言，世界各地的工人都希望在家呆两天，比他们能得到的多一整天。在英语国家，在家办公的程度已经最高，因此人们对更多在家办公的需求也越来越大。这种趋势正在蔓延到远程工作不太常见的地方（见图 1）。日本和韩国的员工是世界上最常呆在办公室的员工，他们希望每周有超过四分之一的时间独处。欧洲人和拉丁美洲人分别渴望三分之一和一半。

人们持续渴望更多的远程工作并不奇怪。无需与公共交通或拥挤的道路作斗争，节省的时间可以实现更好的工作与生活平衡。帮助运营WFH Research 的斯坦福大学尼古拉斯·布鲁姆 (Nicholas Bloom) 及其同事在一份工作论文*中指出，远程工作平均每天可以节省 72 分钟，一年下来可以节省两周时间。盖洛普去年的一项民意调查显示，员工还表示，他们在远程工作时感觉最投入。平均而言，全球员工对所有这些福利的重视程度相当于工资上涨 8%，这表明有些人会采取减薪来保留自己的特权。

直到最近，随着企业试图在大流行后的招聘热潮中吸引员工，员工的需求和雇主的计划似乎在美国这个研究最充分的市场上趋同。这种趋同正在逐渐减弱（见图 2）。与此同时，疫情也巩固了在家工作的模式。目前， WFH Research 调查的员工中有三分之一采用混合或完全远程安排。这些做法并不容易放松。

随着劳动力市场开始降温，对远程工作的打击发生并非巧合。华尔街和硅谷不断深化的裁员将权力交还给企业。然而，即使在科技和金融领域，一些员工也坚持自己的立场。 5 月，亚马逊表示，有 300 名员工因电子帝国的重返工作岗位政策而举行罢工（组织者称人数接近 2,000 人）。其他公司正在悄悄地适应时代，也许认识到采取更灵活的方法是不可避免的。英国汇丰银行(HSBC)正计划从金丝雀码头的 45 层大楼搬迁到伦敦金融城较小的办公楼。德勤和毕马威这两家专业服务巨头计划减少办公室占地面积，以支持更多远程工作。在家工作之战双方之间的差距可能仍在缩小。问题在于，是老板还是被老板的收益最高。 ■

*“全球在家工作：2023 年报告”，作者：CG Aksoy、JM Barrero、N. Bloom、SJ Davis、M. Dolls、P. Zarate

; Mon, 10 Jul 2023 19:32:33 GMT /内容/jgo0n1m46ce2ib1t28lcemenqeg169gp https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/10/the-fight-over-working-from-home-goes-global How white-collar warriors gear up for the day

《伊利亚特》是一个关于荣耀与诸神、复仇与仁慈、死亡与不朽的故事。如果你仔细观察的话，这也是一个职场传奇。这部史诗以一对名叫阿伽门农和阿喀琉斯的同事之间的大争吵开始。众神是高层领导团队，从高处降临，造成彻底的混乱。在本书的大部分内容中，阿基里斯这个天才混蛋的原型都在罢工。这对于失去了最佳表现的希腊管理团队来说是一个大问题。人力资源部的代表团未能赢得阿基里斯的支持。然而，最终他回到了办公室，一切都很好（特洛伊人可能不同意）。

诚然，21 世纪的工作场所与《伊利亚特》之间的相似之处并不准确。今天，在玫瑰色的黎明中闪闪发光的剑和矛越来越少了；地板上的大脑物质有点少。但要了解现代与荷马史诗的联系，请看看阿喀琉斯为重返工作岗位所做的准备。

他在第 19 卷中说道：“现在我要武装自己准备战争。”从乔叟到兰博，阿喀琉斯的武装就是从那时起的准备场景的先驱。但它也与当前的日常仪式相呼应。阿喀琉斯穿上青铜护腿和闪亮的胸甲；员工会选择周末不穿的衣服。阿喀琉斯戴上他的金羽头盔；通勤者戴着 Bose 耳机。荷马英雄拿起火神赫菲斯托斯铸造的盾牌。办公室职员将笔记本电脑和充电器塞进背包里。

大多数白领武装都发生在家里，但并非全部。它也发生在前往战场的途中，因为粉盒出现并且在地铁上化妆。有时转变发生在办公室本身。运动鞋换成了高跟鞋。穿着莱卡服装的同事从视野中消失，并以不那么令人讨厌的方式出现。

战斗可能即将到来，但它不会立即到来，无论你是米尔米顿的国王还是帐户中的巴里。在真正的行动开始之前，两者都需要跨越门槛。在荷马史诗中，阿喀琉斯一直在营地里等待战争。当希腊人得知他将重新加入战斗时，他出现在海边。战斗开始前有一场盛宴（阿喀琉斯拒绝进食；也许没有素食选择）。一旦武装起来，他就登上战车，“像太阳神海伯利安一样辉煌”奔赴前线。

对于远程工作者来说，他们的个人生活和职业生活之间的差距可能很窄：从冰箱走到客厅（然后再回来，然后再回来）。这是一个问题。进入工作场所意味着穿上不同的角色和不同的衣服——你，但要有更多的自制力。当家庭和工作之间有明确的界限时，这种转变就更容易实现。

上班族还有更多的门槛需要跨越。他们早上出现在街上，走向自己的办公桌。他们走进一家咖啡馆喝早间咖啡；端着杯子快步走是让同胞知道你有报酬的最简单的方式。在某个时候，他们将第一次见到同事。如果他们非常不幸，这次会面将在通勤开始时进行，并涉及在公共交通工具上进行长达 40 分钟的令人痛苦的闲聊。通常，这仅意味着办公室关闭。

然后，工作人员必须进入办公室。有保安人员迎接、刷卡通行证和按下按钮。此时，来到办公室的访客将参与额外的武装场景，他们在登记簿上签下自己的名字，字迹难以辨认，并获得一根挂绳。海伯利安，确实如此。

采取行动的时刻迫在眉睫。在特洛伊城墙外，阿喀琉斯像“一头凶猛的狮子”一样向前冲去。一场大屠杀开始了，最终以赫克托的死而结束。白领也必须为未来的一天做好最后的准备。背包脱落，电脑打开。这位受薪英雄跳上前来，下巴冒着白沫，咬下最后一口羊角面包。键盘和地毯上布满了面包屑。输入密码，加载轮旋转，心率保持完全相同。是时候了。

荷马永远不会以办公室史诗闻名：死亡和荣耀保证了比电子邮件和会议更戏剧性的叙述。但当你穿上工作服，换上职业装，无情地敲响你的第一把钥匙时，你就不仅仅是一名步兵了。你是一个小小的阿喀琉斯。 ■

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 11:54:57 GMT /内容/j1bb5fa7vt30gj2q3vvurlol9mg3gp4o https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/06/how-white-collar-warriors-gear-up-for-the-day A Lego-lover’s guide to preparing for the AI age

在伦敦设计博物馆，中国艺术家艾未未正在举办一个展览，其中包括一件基于克劳德·莫奈三联画的15米长作品《睡莲#1》。仔细一看，它是由65万块乐高积木组成的——将莫奈的印象派融入到艾未未所说的“数字化、像素化的语言”中。这是乐高本身的一个很好的类比。这家丹麦玩具制造商的长期使命是将人类创造力的源泉：塑料砖数字化和像素化。

管理咨询公司麦肯锡的三位数字专家在他们的新书《Rewired》中介绍了乐高的转型，该书概述了企业在数字化时代进行自我重建的注意事项。请注意：数字化转型的语言是对普通英语的背叛。这听起来更像是企业瑜伽，而不是软件开发的马拉松。高管人员需要保持一致。团队是 Pod。动作敏捷。定义你的向下域。麦肯锡吸取了 200 家公司的经验教训，尽管内容繁琐，但仍提供了清晰的信息。但为了让大家更容易理解，熊彼特将使用乐高积木作为指南来帮助说明麦肯锡的一些见解。称之为通向生成人工智能（ AI ）的黄砖路。

首先，这是一条漫长而艰难的道路，充满了失败。乐高是一个罕见的成功故事。它的旅程开始于2003年，当时电子游戏兴起，它经历了一次濒临死亡的经历，它惊慌失措，疯狂创新，几乎让自己破产。为了解决供应链混乱这一主要问题，它在全球范围内引入了单一的企业软件系统。该系统一直延续到今天，并随着乐高扩展到中国等新市场、电子商务等新业态以及美国和越南等新工厂地点而不断扩大。为了迎接像素化的游戏世界，乐高推出了“星球大战”主题的数字游戏，并开发了自己的系列游戏，例如幻影忍者和奇玛，其中的视频游戏、电影和电视节目大受欢迎。

2019 年，乐高推出了新的五年转型计划，旨在适应直接面向消费者销售、在线零售与大型零售店以及屏幕时代数字游戏的世界。时机受到启发。它始于新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 大流行导致世界陷入封锁之前不久，当时数字化战略成为生死攸关的问题。它很快就产生了结果。尽管很难排除数字化的确切贡献，但自 2018 年以来，乐高的销售额几乎翻了一番，达到超过 90 亿美元，超过了其主要竞争对手美泰 (Mattel) 和孩之宝 (Hasbro)。 2022 年，其在线门户网站的访问量增长了 38%。它与视频游戏公司 Epic 合作，探索虚拟宇宙。

然而，这一旅程仍然是艰难的。困难包括从一种以逐家商店的销售额来衡量成功的系统转变为根据公司在全球范围内在线销售的表现、在谷歌和亚马逊上的排名以及软件的有效性来判断的系统。麦肯锡的作者在第一页强调了此类挑战。他们表示，在麦肯锡最近的一项调查中，大约 90% 的公司制定了某种数字化战略，但他们获得的收入增长还不到预期的三分之一。此外，行业内部的成功率比行业之间的成功率更加不平衡。最好的零售商可能比普通高科技公司的数字生产力更高，而最差的零售商可能和最差的政府实体一样糟糕。

To make a success of it requires learning the second lesson: what McKinsey calls having a top-down strategy and a road map (or in Lego terms, a clear instruction manual). For Lego, it helped that the family-owned business had long had a command-and-control approach to management. Its digital strategy involved a single plan, created by a 100-strong executive team and approved by the board, that encompassed the whole organisation. McKinsey notes that when transformations stall, it is often because executives talk past each other, have pet projects, spread investments too thin or have “more pilots than there are on an aircraft-carrier”, as Rodney Zemmel, one of the authors, puts it. It also needs to be ambitious enough to generate momentum, with financial results measured constantly. McKinsey's rule of thumb is that a digital transformation should aim to increase earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation by 20% or more.

Third comes the question of whether to build a new digital infrastructure or buy it. The answer is mostly to build. Rather like Lego's eight-studded bricks—six of which can be combined 915m ways—there are many software applications on the market that can be combined to create proprietary systems. But the job of orchestrating them should not be outsourced. Take Lego: it started its latest digital transformation with engineers making up less than 30% of staff. Since then it has increased the number of systems and software engineers by 150%. Mr Zemmel notes that five years ago, the trend was to hire from Silicon Valley. That was “a good way to change the company dress code, but not a great way to change the company culture”. Since then more companies have been retraining their existing tech workers and embedding them throughout the organisations in more front-line roles.

The gen-AI Weiwei way

Some of these lessons apply to generative AI . Mr Zemmel says it is relatively easy to launch pilots with the technology, such as the humanlike Chat GPT . The problem is embedding the AI models across the organisation in a safe, unbiased way. It needs a top-down strategy. As for building or buying, Mr Zemmel says it may be a “waste of time” to build proprietary models when the software industry is doing that anyway. The key is to work in-house on the things that give you a decisive advantage in the market. For Lego, AI is still in the future, though some of its brick enthusiasts are already using Chat GPT -like programs to come up with new ways of building things. Mostly they fail, but one day anyone may be able to create a Monet. The yellow-brick road is unending. ■

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 11:54:57 GMT /content/ak0mttavm3ckvutv62pqjqmbau370prh https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/06/a-lego-lovers-guide-to-preparing-for-the-ai-age The Musk-Zuckerberg social-media smackdown

I n one corner is Mark Zuckerberg: 39 years old, five foot seven inches and, if his selfies are to be believed, a wizard at jiu-jitsu. In the other corner stands Elon Musk: 13 years older, six inches taller and considerably heavier, with a special move known as the walrus (“I just lie on top of my opponent & do nothing”). The two billionaires have agreed to a cage fight, with Mr Musk saying on June 29th that it might take place at the Roman Colosseum.

The rumble in Rome may not happen. Neither the Italian government nor Mr Musk's mother seems keen. But the new-media moguls are also limbering up for a more consequential fight. On July 5th Meta, Mr Zuckerberg's firm, added a new app to its social-media empire. Threads, a text-based network, looks a lot like Twitter, the app Mr Musk bought last October for $44bn. An almighty social-media smackdown is about to begin.

Mr Musk's tenure at Twitter has been bruising for many parties. About 80% of the nearly 8,000 employees he inherited have been laid off, to cut costs. Amid a glitchy service, users have started to drift away, believes eMarketer, a research firm (see chart). The introduction on July 1st of a paywall, limiting the number of tweets that can be seen by those who do not cough up $8 a month, may repel more. Advertisers have fled: Twitter's ad sales this year will be 28% lower than last, forecasts eMarketer. In May Fidelity, a financial-services firm, estimated that the company had lost about two-thirds of its value since Mr Musk agreed to buy it.

From this chaos, the clearest winner is Mr Zuckerberg. By 2021 his business had become synonymous with misinformation and bile. He then irked investors by using his all-powerful position at the firm to pour billions into the metaverse, an unproven passion project that looks years away from making money. On July 4th two years ago he drew ridicule after posting a video of himself vaingloriously surfing a hydrofoil holding an American flag. No one in Silicon Valley was more polarising.

Today Mr Musk's erratic handling of Twitter makes Mr Zuckerberg's stewardship of Meta look like a model of good corporate governance. And although Twitter's new freewheeling approach to content moderation has delighted some conservatives—including Ron DeSantis, governor of Florida, who launched his presidential bid in a glitch-filled live audio session on the app—liberals find it increasingly hard to stomach. Mr Musk remains more popular than Mr Zuckerberg among Americans (who also fancy his odds in the cage), according to polls from YouGov. But as the controversies at Twitter rumble on, and as politicians turn their fire on another social app, the Chinese-owned TikTok, Mr Zuckerberg's approval rating is now the highest it has been in over three years.

Meta eyes another, commercial victory. Various startups have tried to capitalise on Twitter's travails, with little success. Mastodon, a decentralised social network with a single employee, said that by November it had added more than 2m members since the Twitter deal closed. But people found it fiddly; by June it had 61% fewer users than at its November peak, estimates Sensor Tower, another data firm. Truth Social, Donald Trump's conservative social network, has failed to gain traction, especially since Mr Musk steered Twitter rightwards. The latest pretender, Bluesky, faces the same struggle to achieve critical mass.

Meta's effort, Threads, has a better shot. Cloning rivals is what Meta does best. In 2016, as Snapchat's disappearing “stories” became popular, Mr Zuckerberg unveiled Instagram Stories, a similar product which helped to keep Instagram on top. Last year, as TikTok's short videos became a threat, Meta rolled out Reels, a near-identical format that lives within Instagram and Facebook. In April Mr Zuckerberg said Reels had helped to increase the time spent on Instagram by nearly a quarter.

Threads also has a head start. Unlike Reels, it is its own app. But it lets Instagrammers use their existing login details and follow all the same people with one click. Some 87% of Twitter users already use Instagram, according to DataReportal, a research firm; they now have a near-frictionless alternative to Twitter. Will they switch? For some, it may be enough to have a network that is “sanely run”, as Meta's chief product officer put it recently. Mr Musk may have provided a shove to the others by announcing a paywall days before Threads' launch.

By Meta's standards, Twitter's business is tiny, with one-eighth as many users as Facebook, the world's largest social network. In 2021 Twitter's revenue was $5.1bn, against Meta's $116bn. And those meagre earnings bring big problems. Few platforms attract as many angry oddballs as Twitter. Lately Meta has shied away from promoting news, which brings political controversy and seems not to delight users. News is a big part of what Twitter does.

Why, then, does Mr Zuckerberg think Threads is worth the headache? One reason is advertising. Twitter has never made much money out of its users because it knows little about them. Between half and two-thirds of those who read tweets are not logged in, estimates Simon Kemp of DataReportal. Many registered users are “lurkers”, who view others' feeds but seldom engage. Meta, which knows a lot about its users from its other apps, can hit them with well-targeted ads in Threads from day one. And the brand-focused adverts that work best on Twitter would complement the direct-response ads that Facebook and Instagram specialise in.

Meta's other possible motive relates to artificial intelligence ( AI ). Models behind human-sounding apps like Chat GPT place a premium on big troves of text. Online forums like Reddit are scrambling to monetise the billions of words that they hold. Mr Musk has said that Twitter's paywall is a response to “EXTREME levels of data scraping” by AI firms. In setting up a text-based network alongside the visual feeds of Facebook and Instagram, Meta gets a source of rich language data. Threads is much more than an ad platform, says Mr Kemp. “Zuck is playing the AI content-feeding game.” Whether Meta licensed the data to others or used it in its own AI projects, it would be a new growth story to tell investors.

Launching a social network is hard. Even with its 3.8bn existing users Meta has had its share of failures: Facebook Dating remains unloved and the company's gaming and shopping initiatives have yet to take off. But as Twitter bleeds users and advertisers, and as Mr Musk's management continues on its eccentric path, the opportunity is becoming bigger. Regardless of who prevails in the cage, Mr Zuckerberg may come away with the spoils. ■

; Tue, 04 Jul 2023 19:49:13 GMT /content/jr98j1usircc60jou3l3vig2nqjaqc41 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/04/the-musk-zuckerberg-social-media-smackdown In its tech war with America, China brings out the big guns

I N THE TECH battle between America and China , the Western power has been more aggressive of late. Last year President Joe Biden's administration laid out harsh restrictions limiting Chinese artificial-intelligence ( AI ) companies' access to American technology. America has also been coaxing allies to follow its lead. On June 30th the Netherlands, under pressure from the White House, announced that it would restrict the sales of some chipmaking equipment to China: ASML , a Dutch maker of the world's most advanced lithography machines, will from now on sell Chinese customers only low-yield devices for etching cutting-edge chips. On July 4th the Wall Street Journal reported that the American government may be preparing to curb Chinese use of American cloud-computing services, which enable Chinese AI firms to circumvent America's earlier sanctions by taking advantage of the cloud provider's high-end processors without owning chips of their own.

China's communist authorities had so far responded to this barrage of tats with a single, relatively meagre tit: in May it barred some Chinese companies from using memory chips made by Micron, a company from Idaho. But on July 3rd it brought out a bigger gun, saying that it would impose export controls on gallium and germanium, two metals used in high-end semiconductors.

The new export controls will come into effect on August 1st. Unlike the Micron ban, which has little impact beyond one American chipmaker's top line, restrictions on the sale of chip metals could reverberate across the global chip industry. China supplies about 80% of the world's gallium and germanium. America may source as much as 50% of its germanium supply from China, according to Jefferies, an investment bank.

An all-out ban could disrupt the production of a wide range of existing products, including chips, screens, fibre-optic gear and solar panels. It may also stymie the development of next-generation technologies. Chipmakers hope gradually to replace the silicon used in most processors with gallium nitride or silicon carbide, both of which can handle higher voltages. Gallium and germanium may also be useful in electric vehicles, nuclear energy and other devices, including weapons.

The Chinese move comes at a delicate moment in Sino-American relations . Despite their respective tech manoeuvres, in recent months both sides have also been talking of stabilising relations. Janet Yellen, America's treasury secretary, was expected to arrive in Beijing for talks as we published this. The visit follows a meeting in Washington in May between China's and America's commerce secretaries, and a trip to China in late June by Antony Blinken, America's secretary of state, in which he briefly met Xi Jinping, China's leader, and other senior officials.

China hawks in Washington may argue that China's bite is weaker than its bark. Like some of the American restrictions, China's new rules would require exporters to seek government approval and export licences. The Chinese government may well grant these quite freely: after all, a total prohibition would hurt Chinese exporters, who sell a lot of germanium and gallium to American customers. But Mr Biden should make no mistake. China is showing that it will not roll over—and that it can strike back. Expect an increasingly evenly balanced tit-for-tat. ■

; Mon, 03 Jul 2023 20:01:15 GMT /content/cd6bbmh1evh5ppvlkpal6s8uu91o1g51 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/07/03/can-a-viable-industry-emerge-from-the-hydrogen-shakeout The potential and the plight of the middle manager

N othing turns on management theorists more than conflicting incentives. (If the idea of an aroused management theorist has ruined your breakfast, sorry.) They ruminate on financial motives—the adverse impact that individual bonus schemes might have on team collaboration, say. They churn out studies and books on the competing interests of shareholders and the executives who act on their behalf.

A new paper, published by Achyuta Adhvaryu of the University of California, San Diego, and Emir Murathanoglu and Anant Nyshadham of the University of Michigan, casts fresh light on the problem. It shows that clashing incentives are not always financial, and that conflicts can occur even between different levels of management. In the process it underlines that a much-mocked group deserves to be taken far more seriously.

The authors examined the decisions of middle managers at Shahi Exports, one of India's largest garment-makers. The firm has about 70 factories, where multiple teams of cutters, sewers and finishers produce clothing. In their study the academics tracked which team supervisors were being recommended for soft-skills training by their own managers, and then looked at the effect of that training on productivity and retention.

What they found was curious. On average the training worked. Teams whose supervisors had been through the course saw big productivity gains compared with control groups. But these advances were distributed unevenly. Teams whose supervisors were most highly recommended by middle managers for training experienced no productivity gains; the benefits were concentrated on supervisors who were less recommended. The pattern for retention was the reverse: there was a big drop in subsequent quit rates among supervisors who had been highly recommended by their managers, and little change among less recommended ones.

Mr Adhvaryu et al look at a variety of explanations for this strange pattern and conclude that it reflects a deliberate calculation: managers were nominating those supervisors whom they regarded as flight risks. That did not necessarily suit the interests of the company's senior leaders. But it did suit the interests of middle managers, who bear the burden of filling in for missing supervisors and training new ones. Losing workers, in short, makes their lives a lot harder. Retention matters more to them than productivity.

The paper provides three lessons, beyond the hoary one that incentives matter. The first is that agency problems can occur wherever power is delegated. A decentralised organisation often makes a ton of sense, but it also risks introducing layers of competing interests. Another recent paper by Ingrid Haegele, then of the University of California, Berkeley, found that German managers at a big manufacturing company tried to hoard the best workers for their own teams. When managers are themselves about to move into new positions, they have less incentive to discourage good employees from job-hopping. Ms Haegele found that workers' applications for internal promotions more than doubled during these temporary periods of selflessness.

The second lesson is that middle managers deserve respect more than ridicule. The type of behaviour observed by the academics is possible because these managers have valuable private information: they know who is thinking of leaving the company and who is worth keeping. People in corner offices and boardrooms are usually too distant from the action to have this kind of insight.

All of which means that middle managers can have a hugely beneficial effect on the performance of the workforce if the incentives are right. The third lesson from Shahi Exports is that money is not always the root problem. Its middle managers were making their training recommendations to avoid the extra work that comes from higher churn.

That might make them sound lazy. In fact, they are suffering from a common problem. “Power to the Middle” is a forthcoming book on middle managers by Emily Field, Bryan Hancock and Bill Schaninger, a trio of consultants at McKinsey. It argues that a lack of time and resources bedevils these unfortunate souls everywhere. A survey of 700 middle managers conducted for the book finds that they are spending one full day a week on administrative tasks. Replacing good workers is never fun, but it is a lot worse if a manager is already running on empty. You don't need to be a theorist to work that out. ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /content/s22pt586j8qje5ne5d9cbe3s4ja9c0ga https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/the-potential-and-the-plight-of-the-middle-manager Meet the world’s most flirtatious sovereign-wealth fund

Y our columnist was in Riyadh in 2016 when Muhammad bin Salman, wearing robes and sandals, announced his Vision 2030, aimed at ending what the crown prince described as the kingdom's addiction to oil. Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler talked of selling shares in Saudi Aramco, the world's biggest oil company, to fund a giant sovereign-wealth fund ( SWF ), worth $2trn, to invest in diverse non-oil industries. He would be its chairman, benefactor and mastermind. It was heady stuff, even if some of it sounded unhinged in a hidebound autocracy like Saudi Arabia. The most striking thing occurred later when a palace official invited Schumpeter to a café. Young men and women sat without head coverings, flirting openly. The rule-breaking atmosphere was electric.

Today, the Saudi SWF , called the Public Investment Fund ( PIF ), is becoming the goliath Prince Muhammad dreamed about. The value of its assets has ballooned to $700bn, it has over 1,400 employees and a rising global profile, and, like those youthful café-dwellers, it has discovered the joys of public flirtation. Whether revolutionising golf, buying Europe's football glitterati, betting on star video-gaming companies, building an airline from scratch or turning Aston Martin electric, the pif cannot stop orchestrating one headline-grabbing deal after another. It has come “screaming onto the scene” with an “everything, everywhere, all-at-once investment approach”, says Robert Mogielnicki of the Arab Gulf States Institute, a think-tank based in Washington, DC . Yet it may not be as promiscuous as it sounds. Look carefully and there is more than adolescent impetuousness to its investment approach.

It starts with the PIF ’s mandate. Like many SWF s, one aim is to redirect the country's oil wealth into global assets for long-term growth. But it is also required to nurture a diversified economy at home in case demand for oil drops. It has aggressive expansion plans. It wants to amass over $1trn in assets under management by 2025 and at least to double that by 2030, making it the biggest SWF on Earth. It is unlikely that much of that growth will come from investment returns, not least because over two-thirds of its assets are in Saudi Arabia. Instead it will require more public disbursements, such as the 4% of Aramco shares, at a value of almost $80bn, that it received in April. How much money is available will depend on oil prices, which are well below the highs of last year.

It is not only reliant on oil. Mr Mogielnicki notes that the PIF ’s asset values could increase if it attracts co-investors into its Saudi projects. That is where its domestic strategy dovetails with its foreign one. It has taken a 75% stake in four Saudi sports teams, which may attract more investment if they are privatised, pushing up their value. He believes that over time, co-investment could also increase the worth of some of its industrial and tourist megaprojects, such as Neom, which the PIF is aiming to turn into a desert-city Utopia. The kingdom needs visitors—both well-heeled tourists and deep-pocketed investors—to turn vision into reality. For that, the PIF needs to put Saudi Arabia on the map.

Its most eye-catching gambit in that pursuit is sport. Whether or not it pulls off the golfing megamerger of the century, it is already now a name to be reckoned with. Its purchase of Newcastle United, an English Premier League club, was a down-payment for a bigger ambition; to turn the kingdom into a football powerhouse. Luring players like Cristiano Ronaldo, who recently trousered a $200m salary to play for a Saudi team, is part of that strategy. Don't be surprised if such influencers are used as character references to secure the rights to host the FIFA World Cup in 2030.

Such investment has led to accusations of “sportswashing”, ie, using prominent brand ambassadors to obscure appalling human-rights abuses, such as the murder in 2018 of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi-born columnist for the Washington Post . Yet image laundering also has economic logic. Qatar showed with last year's World Cup the value of what Max Castelli of ubs , a bank, calls the “prestige element” of hosting big events, regardless of financial returns. Sport costs the PIF relatively little. Yet it provides a lot of bang for buck in the global market for attention.

The PIF is making other strategic investments that attract less hullabaloo, but also have domestic ramifications. Two of note are gaming and clean energy. In February the PIF became the biggest foreign shareholder in Nintendo, a Japanese gaming company, to add to a collection of assets including Activision Blizzard and Electronic Arts. It hopes to turn Neom into a gaming-development hub. As for decarbonisation, one of its biggest foreign investments is in Lucid, a California-based electric-vehicle ( EV ) maker. On June 26th Lucid won a contract to provide electric motors and battery systems to Aston Martin, a British luxury carmaker, in which the PIF is also a big shareholder. Unsurprisingly, Lucid is building its first overseas factory in Saudi Arabia.

The PIF ’s EV investment illustrates both its dreams and a less silver-lined reality. Some of its biggest bets have seriously underperformed. That includes Lucid, venture-capital investments via SoftBank's Vision Fund, and its stake in Uber, a ride-hailing firm. At home, its record is also tarnished. Saudi National Bank, one of its biggest holdings, lost a fortune in March on an ill-timed investment in Credit Suisse, a Swiss bank. Megaprojects such as Neom have become so grandiose, they risk looking farcical (and Neom is under human-rights scrutiny over treatment of the Howeitat tribe that lived on the land). If investors are seduced, it will be by the promise of returns, not by the razzle-dazzle of Potemkin villages.

Lifting the veil

Yet one big thing that the PIF has in its favour is its openness. According to Diego Lopez, boss of Global SWF , a data gatherer, no sovereign fund advertises its ambitions so publicly. That no doubt is a way of enhancing Prince Muhammad's reputation for boldness. It also puts the PIF under extra pressure to make sure his vision does not all go horribly wrong. ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /content/a13ipkq7g77gl32jo5418o1cbn8pd669 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/meet-the-worlds-most-flirtatious-sovereign-wealth-fund Why Asia’s super-app companies are stuck in a rut

A merican technology barons occasionally bemoan the lack in the West of “super-apps”, multifaceted online platforms offering a variety of different services. But the global interest in the business model belies the difficulties facing existing super-apps in Asia.

Their recent performance has disappointed (see chart). Collectively, the market capitalisation of Singapore's Sea and Grab, South Korea's Coupang and Kakao, Japan's Rakuten, and the parent company of India's Paytm has declined by around 60% since the end of 2021. None of the firms is the same; they each make money from a blend of mobile gaming, social media, e-commerce, ride-sharing and financial payments. What they have in common is an aspiration to bundle together a variety of services which complement one another on one app. They had hoped hoping to emulate Chinese companies, such as Tencent's WeChat and Alibaba's Alipay, which pioneered the business model.

But the newer Asian super-apps have been put under huge pressure by a rapidly changing environment. Funding, which was once cheap and plentiful, has dried up, making ambitious growth plans harder to finance. James Lloyd at Citigroup, a bank, notes that China's super-apps started with a core of profitable and engaging businesses (e-commerce for Alipay and social media in the case of WeChat), which other services were built around. Outside China, few firms have balanced both significant scale and earnings in a similar way.

Kakao, a South Korean firm, most closely fits the bill. Unlike most Asian would-be super-apps, it has been reliably profitable. Yet its share price has declined by 8% this year. Because the company is dominant on its home turf, it is running out of room for further domestic growth. Its ride-hailing arm has a market share in South Korea of as much as 90%, by some estimates. The firm wants to raise the international share of its revenues from 10% today to 30% by 2025—but such global expansion comes at a cost.

At other firms the funding squeeze has inspired ambitions for profitability, which inevitably comes at the expense of previous plans for rapid expansion. GoTo, an Indonesian super-app, created from the merger of Gojek, a ride-hailing company, and Tokopedia, an e-commerce firm, was expected to appoint a former banker, Patrick Walujo, as CEO at its shareholder meeting on June 30th, after we published this. Mr Walujo has stressed that his aim is to make the company profitable.

One Asian consumer-tech firm has bucked this year's trend. The share price of Paytm, a would-be Indian super-app based around digital payments, has rallied by around 60%. The stock is still less than half of its all-time high, reached shortly after it floated in November 2021, and the firm has yet to make a profit. Nonetheless, its rising share price may reflect something companies elsewhere in Asia lack: a single, large and growing domestic market to work with. Whether that potential for scale proves enough for a more sustainable future for Paytm has yet to be seen.

The idea of a company using a single platform to offer a variety of services to consumers has an intuitive appeal. But after more than a decade of discussion about the coming dominance of super-apps, many of the Asian firms are still struggling to find a balance between size and profitability. With no end in sight to higher funding costs, a speedy recovery for these one-time darlings of tech investors is hard to foresee. ■
